Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Researching how the discovery of a biofluorescent flying squirrel led to discoveries of more fluorescent mammals, such as wombats, bilbies, echidnas and bandicoots, as scientists collaborated with other scientists across fields of science and internationally

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Researching why European naturalists and scientists first thought the platypus was a fake animal, and how scientists such as those in the Australian Platypus Conservancy are collaborating in ongoing research to understand the features and behaviours of platypuses

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Exploring why developing new erosion mitigation techniques such as contour banks and strip-cropping requires the collaboration of geologists, hydrologists and farmers

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Researching how contemporary restorative ecology adapts and builds on the traditional ecological knowledges of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Researching how scientists, manufacturers and farmers collaborated to use compressed gases such as carbon dioxide (CO2) in the development of fire extinguishers, planting crops and paintball

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Examining why ecologists collaborate with engineers and computer scientists to develop remote sensing techniques, identify patterns in habitat change and make predictions about the survival of organisms

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge changes over time, often resulting from collaboration or by building on the work of others, and leads to advances in science
Elaboration: Constructing a timeline to show how contributions and collaborations of scientists, mathematicians, engineers and astronomers from many countries have advanced ideas about space and the solar system through development of models, gathering of evidence and, more recently, space exploration

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Examining how communities use knowledge of erosion processes to design landscape features that reduce erosion in fragile environments

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Examining how knowledge of erosion is used by park rangers to design rules such as keeping to paths and not climbing sandstone, as well as built features such as channel drains on paths, railings and barriers to protect park environments and Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ cultural sites

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Researching the impacts of light pollution and exploring how communities have used scientific knowledge to reduce light pollution, such as by using covered light bulbs facing downwards in streetlights, automated systems to turn off streetlights, and motion sensors on outdoor lights in homes and in public places

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Investigating how people use knowledge of conditions that reduce mould or bacterial growth when considering food packaging and storage

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Investigating why underground power cables were developed and how local government authorities use scientific knowledge about power safety when considering converting to underground power

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge, skills and data can be used by individuals and communities to identify problems, consider responses and make decisions
Elaboration: Exploring how communities consider the impact of reversible reactions when designing guidelines about the ability of materials to be recycled

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Identifying the physical conditions in an aquatic or terrestrial habitat and how they change over time

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Investigating how changes to physical conditions such as salinity, soil type, sunlight and temperature affect plant growth

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Examining how changes in physical conditions such as temperature, light availability and rainfall affect animals such as corals, honey bees and flying foxes, and predict impacts of these changes

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Investigating Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ knowledges and understandings of the physical conditions necessary for the survival of certain plants and animals, for example researching the collaborative work of the Aboriginal Peoples of the Murray–Darling Basin wetlands with government and scientific groups to restore the wetlands through water research, planning and management, including reintroducing salt-tolerant native flora to improve ecosystem health and biodiversity

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Investigating changes in physical conditions that are the result of human activity, and exploring the impact of these on organisms, such as the impact of urban lighting on nocturnal and migratory animals

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Investigating the effect of physical conditions on the growth of bread-mould colonies in sealed plastic bags

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Habitats can be described by their physical conditions; changing the physical conditions of a habitat, including by human activity, may affect the growth and survival of organisms
Elaboration: Recognising that environmental conditions can affect stages of life, such as ponds drying up, seeds requiring water to germinate, and temperatures being too high or low for eggs to hatch

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Identifying physical and behavioural characteristics that enable a plant or animal to survive, such as being able to see in dim light or being nocturnal

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Exploring features of plants and animals that enable them to survive in Australia’s desert environments, such as those of the bottle tree (boab) and the water-holding frog

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Analysing the advantages and disadvantages of particular adaptations, for example having 2 or 4 feet, having different-shaped beaks, having gills/lungs, having coloured/scented flowers or having smooth/hairy leaves

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Investigating how camouflage is used by animals to hide from predators and to ambush prey

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Using physical or digital simulations to investigate how the shapes of animals’ body parts, such as the beak of a particular bird species, influence their ability to find food and survive in a specific environment

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Exploring how variation in offspring over time has resulted in animals being more or less able to survive in particular environments, for example how the necks of modern giraffes are longer than those of their ancestors, or the ability of chameleons to change colour and the long hibernation time of eastern pygmy possums

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Organisms have evolved over time, as seen in fossils and scientific records; the structural features and behaviours of living organisms enable them to thrive in their environments
Elaboration: Investigating Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ knowledges of the structural features of certain species and how those features can be utilised through biomimicry, for example construction of fishing spears that demonstrate the adoption of stingray defence mechanisms such as the barb on a stingray’s tail

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Using role-play to model the arrangement and motion of particles in solids, liquids and gases, and exploring, with guidance, ideas about what exists between particles

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Using a large plastic syringe to observe the compressibility of air compared with that of liquids, and observing a virtual demonstration of coloured gases being compressed and providing an explanation for the change in colour intensity

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Exploring examples that demonstrate that gases have mass, such as blowing air through straws to move objects and using a balance to compare an empty balloon to one filled with air

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Investigating mixtures by setting up sensory bins with a variety of materials that can be sorted and mixed, such as beads, rice, pasta, buttons, coins and plastic lids

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Identifying common examples of mixtures and solutions in their daily lives

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Making lemonade (a solution) by dissolving lemon juice and sugar (solutes) into water (a solvent)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The observable properties of matter (solids, liquids and gases) can be explained by modelling the motion and arrangement of their particles; mixtures (including solutions) can be formed by combining 2 or more different substances
Elaboration: Recognising Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ knowledges and understandings of solids, liquids and gases, and how these knowledges are applied in a range of processes and practices, including the use of ochres and in cooking

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Discussing what makes a change reversible or irreversible, using everyday examples

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Examining the substances produced in cooking and rusting, and comparing them with the original substances

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Comparing how the amount of heat energy added may affect whether a change in state or an irreversible change occurs, such as when heating chocolate

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Investigating solubility by observing which common substances dissolve in water, for example sand, salt, sugar, oil, metals and plastic

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Describing how dissolved substances are reclaimed from solutions

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Exploring how reversible changes can be used to recycle materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Changes to substances may be reversible, in which case the substance may be recovered, or irreversible, in which case new substances are formed; for most substances a change of state or dissolving in water is reversible, while irreversible changes include cooking and rusting
Elaboration: Investigating Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ knowledges of reversible processes such as the use of resins as adhesives in toolmaking to allow repair and reshaping, and of irreversible processes such as when using fuels for torches

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Identifying types of weathering caused mechanically, such as in wind abrasion, cycles of extreme heat or cold and frost-wedging, and biologically, such as by plants and tree roots

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Exploring how erosion can be caused by moving air or moving water and how substances such as surface soil are relocated, and identifying examples of erosion on a local or regional scale

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Analysing the difference between weathering and erosion, and comparing the timescales over which these processes can occur

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Modelling the effects of erosion on a simulated landscape and exploring factors that mitigate them

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Investigating how humans have changed local landscapes and predicting the possible effects of these changes on rates of erosion

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Geological processes including weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition can cause slow or rapid changes to Earth’s surface
Elaboration: Considering how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples have been and are impacted by the rapid erosion of sand dunes, and the effect of salt water on culturally significant freshwater swamps

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sudden geological changes or extreme weather conditions can affect Earth’s surface and atmosphere; the impacts of natural hazards, including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and floods, can be reduced by human actions and technological innovations
Elaboration: Considering the effects of significant rainfall, such as during the monsoon season, on the transportation and deposition of river sediments in the Asia–Pacific region

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sudden geological changes or extreme weather conditions can affect Earth’s surface and atmosphere; the impacts of natural hazards, including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and floods, can be reduced by human actions and technological innovations
Elaboration: Investigating major geological events such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and tsunamis

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sudden geological changes or extreme weather conditions can affect Earth’s surface and atmosphere; the impacts of natural hazards, including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and floods, can be reduced by human actions and technological innovations
Elaboration: Recognising that earthquakes can cause tsunamis

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sudden geological changes or extreme weather conditions can affect Earth’s surface and atmosphere; the impacts of natural hazards, including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and floods, can be reduced by human actions and technological innovations
Elaboration: Considering the effect of drought on living and non-living parts of the environment

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sudden geological changes or extreme weather conditions can affect Earth’s surface and atmosphere; the impacts of natural hazards, including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and floods, can be reduced by human actions and technological innovations
Elaboration: Recognising the impact that natural hazards can have on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ cultural heritage and ways that this can be reduced, for example the impact of bushfires on rock art sites and the impact of severe storms on the erosion of coastal shell midden sites

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Exploring simulations of the solar system, such as a pocket solar system, to appreciate the distances and relationships between the Sun and planets

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Recognising that gravity keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Using three-dimensional models or role-play to model how Earth’s rotation on its axis causes day and night

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Using virtual simulations or real-time views of Earth from space to investigate why different regions on Earth, such as the South Pole, have a long period of sunlight and a long period of darkness during one revolution of Earth around the Sun

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Using three-dimensional models to investigate how the tilt of Earth points one hemisphere towards the Sun and the other away at different times of the year, and predicting how this affects the amount of sunlight on the surface of different regions on Earth

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The force of gravity keeps Earth and other planets in the solar system in orbit around the Sun; cyclic observable phenomena, including variable day and night length, can be related to Earth’s tilt, rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun
Elaboration: Researching Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ understandings of the night sky and its use for timekeeping purposes as evidenced in oral cultural records, rock paintings, paintings and stone arrangements

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Distinguishing between natural sources of light (such as glow-worms, the Sun and stars) and artificial ones (such as light bulbs and candles)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Investigating the shadows that are formed when light is completely or partially blocked by an object, such as when using a sundial or shadow puppets, and how shadow length changes with the changing position of the Sun

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Observing refraction of light using prisms or water droplets and examining the rainbow effect produced

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Exploring how hologram videos use the refractive properties of light to create an image that appears to be three-dimensional

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Exploring the use of reflection of light by mirrors, such as in periscopes and mirror mazes

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Light can be produced from many sources; light travels in a straight path, can form shadows, and can be absorbed, transmitted, reflected or refracted by objects
Elaboration: Recognising Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ understanding of refraction as experienced in spearfishing and in shimmering body paint, and of reflection as evidenced by materials selected for construction of housing

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Identifying necessary components for an electric circuit, such as a source of electrical energy; a conducting material such as metal wire, a key or a switch; and a light or electrical device such as a buzzer

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Constructing a real or virtual electrical circuit to examine requirements to allow the flow of electricity, including exploring the construction and role of switches

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Constructing representations of electrical circuits and their components using accepted conventions

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Using electrical circuits and components to demonstrate electrical energy transfer and the transformation of electrical energy into heat, light and sound

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Investigating different electrical conductors and insulators, and examining why they may be used

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials may be electrical insulators or conductors; energy can be transferred and transformed in electrical circuits where the components of a circuit play particular roles in the function of the circuit
Elaboration: Exploring how electricity is used in homes, and identifying electrical hazards and safety measures used to mitigate these hazards

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Investigable questions and reasoned predictions can be used in guiding investigations to identify patterns and test relationships
Elaboration: Posing questions that can be investigated scientifically, such as ‘Do all animals in desert habitats have ways to survive without water?’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Investigable questions and reasoned predictions can be used in guiding investigations to identify patterns and test relationships
Elaboration: Posing investigable questions to identify patterns, such as ‘What type of material is the best conductor and what is the best insulator of electricity?’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Investigable questions and reasoned predictions can be used in guiding investigations to identify patterns and test relationships
Elaboration: Making predictions to test relationships, such as whether a particular arrangement of mirrors will enable viewing around corners

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Investigable questions and reasoned predictions can be used in guiding investigations to identify patterns and test relationships
Elaboration: Making reasoned predictions about the properties of an unknown solid, liquid or gas

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Investigable questions and reasoned predictions can be used in guiding investigations to identify patterns and test relationships
Elaboration: Predicting the relationship between the loudness of a sound and the distance of the sound from its source

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Considering different ways to undertake investigations, such as researching, using trial and error, experimental testing, field observations, using digital tools to record observations, conducting surveys and using simulations

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Using a map or aerial photographs to predict local sites likely to be affected by erosion, and collaboratively planning a field excursion to collect observations

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Identifying the variable being tested, the variable being measured and variables that need to be kept the same in their investigation of the amount of heat energy needed to cause a reversible or irreversible reaction

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Planning and recording the method used in an investigation about the amount of erosion on slopes so that the method is repeatable

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Identifying potential risks to themselves or others when identifying electrical hazards at home and explaining rules for safe processes and use of equipment and materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Repeatable scientific investigations to answer questions can be planned and conducted, including, as appropriate, deciding the variables to be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests, considering potential risks, planning for the safe and ethical use of equipment and materials, and obtaining permissions for investigations conducted on Country and Place or in protected areas
Elaboration: Recognising that scientific investigations on or about Country and Place should involve Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander knowledge holders, and that there may be cultural protocols (ethical principles that guide behaviour in particular situations when interacting with Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples and that are designed to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural and intellectual property rights) in place restricting or prohibiting access

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Equipment can be used to observe, generate, measure and record data with reasonable precision for repeated measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Recording data using standard units such as the volt, ampere, gram, second and metre, and developing the use of standard prefixes for metric units, such as ‘kilo-’ and ‘milli-’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Equipment can be used to observe, generate, measure and record data with reasonable precision for repeated measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Using digital tools such as digital thermometers and soil moisture probes to collect data over time, and recording data in spreadsheets

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Equipment can be used to observe, generate, measure and record data with reasonable precision for repeated measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Discussing why precision is important in measurement, and comparing the precision of different class data sets, for example the growth of radish seeds in different soil environments and the length of shadows at different times of the day

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be organised and processed to show patterns, trends and relationships by constructing representations including tables, graphs and visual or physical models

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be organised and processed to show patterns, trends and relationships by constructing representations including tables, graphs and visual or physical models
Elaboration: Developing a physical model of the Sun and Earth using objects or role-play to describe their relative positions when a place on Earth is in day or night

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be organised and processed to show patterns, trends and relationships by constructing representations including tables, graphs and visual or physical models
Elaboration: Organising information in graphic organisers

ContentDescription: Data and information can be organised and processed to show patterns, trends and relationships by constructing representations including tables, graphs and visual or physical models
Elaboration: Using maps to identify patterns in erosion-site locations or aerial photographs to show effects of erosion over time

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be organised and processed to show patterns, trends and relationships by constructing representations including tables, graphs and visual or physical models
Elaboration: Representing electrical circuits using virtual simulations or circuit diagrams, and indicating the direction of electricity flow

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Methods and findings can be compared with those of others to identify sources of error, to select evidence in support of reasoned explanations and conclusions, and to develop further questions for investigation

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Methods and findings can be compared with those of others to identify sources of error, to select evidence in support of reasoned explanations and conclusions, and to develop further questions for investigation
Elaboration: Recognising errors that could have occurred during testing of the effects of temperature, light availability and rainfall on plants or animals, including changing too many variables, measuring incorrectly or misreading measurements, and in relation to changes in environmental factors

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Methods and findings can be compared with those of others to identify sources of error, to select evidence in support of reasoned explanations and conclusions, and to develop further questions for investigation
Elaboration: Discussing the difference between data and evidence when considering weathering, erosion, transportation and deposition, and examining how evidence is selected

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Methods and findings can be compared with those of others to identify sources of error, to select evidence in support of reasoned explanations and conclusions, and to develop further questions for investigation
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting data collected by different individuals or groups to discuss similarities and differences in findings, and posing questions for further investigation

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific ideas, findings, patterns, trends and relationships can be communicated for a specific purpose and audience, using various presentation formats, scientific vocabulary and digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Constructing a persuasive text for local council to argue for the use of an erosion mitigation strategy in a local area

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific ideas, findings, patterns, trends and relationships can be communicated for a specific purpose and audience, using various presentation formats, scientific vocabulary and digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Constructing a scientific report to share findings, such as how plants responded to changes in physical conditions such as temperature and salinity, and using appropriate vocabulary, data representations, units and sentence structures

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific ideas, findings, patterns, trends and relationships can be communicated for a specific purpose and audience, using various presentation formats, scientific vocabulary and digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Exploring whether there is a ‘correct’ way of representing particles, and creating an animation to teach other students about the motion and arrangement of particles in solids, liquids and gases

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific ideas, findings, patterns, trends and relationships can be communicated for a specific purpose and audience, using various presentation formats, scientific vocabulary and digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Acknowledging and exploring Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ ways of representing and communicating understandings of the night sky, and its use in timekeeping, as evidenced in rock paintings, paintings and stone arrangements

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific ideas, findings, patterns, trends and relationships can be communicated for a specific purpose and audience, using various presentation formats, scientific vocabulary and digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Constructing a poster or slideshow comparing everyday examples of reversible and irreversible changes
